# Why use Git

<img src="images/logogit.png" alt="Git">

1. Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.[https://git-scm.com/]

2. Git eliminates need to save your files as draft-01, draft-02, draft-03, clean-draft, final-draft, and so on. 

3. Git works on any text base file (sorry .docx).

4. Git allows seamless collaboration using "forking", "branching", and "merging".

<img src="images/branching-illustration.png" alt="Branching">

5. Git allows easy data sharing through github [https://github.com/]

<img src="images/Octocat.png" alt="GitHub">

6. Git allows easy data publishing through github

7. Git integrates well other tools scientists often use: RSTudio, LaTex editors, Linux, and much much more. 

# Getting Git on your machine

1. Download Git: https://git-scm.com/downloads

2. Get optional GUI Client: https://git-scm.com/downloads/guis

3. Learn Git in your browser in 15 min: https://try.github.io/levels/1/challenges/1

4. Browse official Git reference manual and educational videos: https://git-scm.com/doc

5. Configure Git your machine for the first time:

Open GitBash (a terminal for Git) and on a command line write the following using `git verb` approach where `verb` is what we actually want to do. 

> `git config --global user.name "Sergey Kirilenko"`

> `git config --global user.email "sergey.kirilenko@kgb.ru"`

> `git config --global color.ui "auto"`

To set your favorite text editor (I highly recommend Atom)

> `git config --global core.editor "atom --wait"`

6. Get a GitHub account for academics

7. Get your Git on!
